Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Large: Sensing Sensors: Compressed sampling with Co-design of Hardware and Algorithms Across Multiple Layers in Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research program will develop and demonstrate theory and techniques for efficient collection, transmission and processing of information in wirelessly-connected sensor networks. This fundamental research is aimed towards development of a revolutionary wireless sensor node, optimized for infrastructure monitoring, and characterized by ultra-low power consumption. Power consumption, installation complexity and installation cost are significant bottlenecks to the widespread deployment of wireless infrastructure monitoring that will be addressed by this research. This research program improves energy efficiency and battery lifetime through the use of compressed sampling in sensing, physical communication and network communication and through the co-design of hardware and algorithms.

A theme of the research is the development of compressive sampling techniques. Compressive sampling techniques will be developed to reduce the number of samples that need to taken by sensors, to optimize the placement of sensing nodes, and to minimize the amount of data transmitted by the sensing nodes. This research will develop new theoretical approaches to signal sampling, to ultra-wideband (UWB) wireless communication of acquired information, and to sensor network architecture and protocols. Development of new theory and algorithms will go hand-in-hand with the development of new circuit techniques. New integrated circuit techniques for analog-to-digital conversion and wireless communication will be developed.

A Center for Structural Health Monitoring through Compressed Sensing will be formed to broaden the impact of this research. The scope of the education component of this program targets grade-school, undergraduate and graduate students. An interdisciplinary curriculum of courses in Math, Civil Engineering and Electrical Engineering will be created. The center will also develop an extensive outreach education program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sensors are vital for monitoring the health of our civil infrastructure. Effective sensing of bridges, buildings and highways can warn of sudden failures and also monitor for problems due to aging. Despite the advantages of infrastructure monitoring, monitoring is expensive and the large amounts of sensor data can be difficult to handle. Wireless monitoring has the advantage that it is far less expensive to deploy than wired sensors. However, the finite lifetime of batteries in a wireless sensor network is a huge challenge since batteries are difficult and expensive to routinely replace. Another challenge is that sensors produce huge amounts of the data – this data is expensive to communicate, store, process and interpret. Needed are techniques to more efficiently collect, transmit and process sensor outputs. These techniques should reduce the energy required for sensing to greatly extend battery life. These techniques should also reduce the amount of data generated by the sensors.

This research program developed and demonstrated theory and techniques for efficient collection, transmission and processing of information in a wireless sensor network. A theme of this research is the use of a recently discovered mathematical technique called compressive sensing to improve sensing. This research applied compressive sensing to make the interface to the sensor more efficient. It was also used compressive sensing to reduce the energy cost of wireless data transmission. Compressive sensing also guided the optimum placement of sensors as well as the processing and interpretation of the sensor outputs. Together, these techniques reduced both energy consumption and also reduced the volume of data. The techniques researched were demonstrated in hardware prototypes. The research was verified and validated with sensors deployed in operational bridge structures in Michigan and California.

This research validated the performance of compressive sensing in reducing the power requirements of wireless bridge monitoring systems on the Telegraph Road Bridge (Monroe, Michigan). Currently, the Telegraph Road Bridge has 31 wireless sensor nodes collecting 57 channels of data including 15 channels of acceleration, 36 channels of strain and 6 channels of temperature. Employing compressive sensing in wireless structural health monitoring systems allows compressed data to be acquired directly without the need for local processing. The research led to new compressive sensing analog to digital converter devices implemented as very efficient integrated circuits. Theory for compressive wireless communication was developed. New efficient radios were demonstrated.

This research was performed by an inter-disciplinary team of researchers from mathematics, civil engineering and electrical engineering. Six faculty and 28 graduate and undergraduate students contributed to the research. The research led to 55 per reviewed conference and journal publications.
